title: Extinction Rebellion grandparents protest "for grandkids' futures" at Buckingham Palace
text:

A group of grannies and grandads motivated by fear for their grandkids’ futures are pushing for drastic government action to halt runaway climate change.

This afternoon several hundred grandparents gathered outside Buckingham Palace to launch Extinction Rebellion (XR) Grandparents, with several being hauled away by the police.

The splinter group’s goal is to force the government to bow to XR’s three key demands through peaceful but disruptive protests.

In their number is Ursula Pethik, a grandmother of five who twice ended up in a police cell after gluing herself first to the A22 in Dover and then Whitehall.

Although Ursula leads a “perfect life” of gardening, tennis and socialising from her East Sussex home, she says she can no longer “live with what is going on”.

(Image: Tim Merry)

(Image: Tim Merry)

“Without wanting to be alarmist, as I understand it we have between 10 and 12 years before the effects of climate change are irreversible,” the retired psychotherapist told Mirror Online.

“It is my generation’s responsibility to do something about it because we plundered the Earth’s resources. I really feel the burden of guilt.”

Another person that burden weighs on is Phillip Lane, a builder and army veteran who served in Northern Ireland during the Troubles.

In recent years the grandfather of eight has become increasingly alarmed by the weather in his hometown of Marsden in West Yorkshire.

“We used to get snow every year for one or two weeks at a time,” the 66-year-old said.

"If it does snow at all now it doesn’t settle. It’s just slush.

(Image: Tim Merry)

(Image: Tim Merry)

“I find it very strange and extremely unsettling. It’s the same temperature all year round now.”

In an attempt to raise awareness about climate change Phillip has twice got himself arrested.

While he found his two 22 hours stints in a cell unpleasant, he still plans on throwing himself into future actions at Leeds Bradford Airport and in Huddersfield.

“My grandkids are between ten months and eight years old, and I just want them to have a decent life,” he said.

“The government is failing us, but I feel optimistic we can get them to approach this (climate change) differently.

“I don’t want to scare my grandkids, but the weather is not going to go back to how it was. All we can do now is mitigate the damage.”

(Image: Tim Merry)

(Image: Tim Merry)

Judy Hardman is a granny of two who joined XR last October after reading the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s report.

She was scared by the panel’s prediction that only 12 years remained before devastating global heating wreaks irreversible environmental havoc.

“It became apparent to me we have such a very small amount of time left to stop this,” the Gloucester woman said.

“Back then my oldest granddaughter Rosa was 3. She will be 15 at the point when we can do nothing to stop runaway climate change.

“I’m a social worker by profession, and social work is all about protecting children from harm.

“I need to tell her I tried to do something."

(Image: Tim Merry)

For the 65-year-old doing something came in the form of her first ever act of civil disobedience in April, when she refused police orders to leave Parliament Square.

For 80-year-old John Scott doing something means spending the time he “has left” raising XR’s profile.

The former Merchant Navy captain has twice been arrested to that end - once while blocking Waterloo Bridge, once while on the way to shut down London City Airport.

Despite finding himself on the wrong side of the law, he continues to have “the greatest respect” for police officers who handled him “professionally, correctly and gently”.

John’s motivation to keep getting arrested stems, as for most of the XR Grandparents, from a fear of leaving a toxic legacy.

“My wife and I are blessed with enough health and energy to enjoy ourselves at our home in Dartmouth,” he said.

(Image: Tim Merry)

“But it has become apparent to us that in the time we have left we have to raise the profile of climate change.

“It’s the major issue facing humanity and life on Earth.

“You have to stand up and be counted, particularly at my age. The consequences are less for me.”

While the grandfather of eight and great-grandfather of three is aware of the challenges the movement faces, he is positive.

“We shouldn’t overburden young people into thinking the planet we’re on is doomed,” he said when asked about whether XR’ arguments are alarmist.

“But these are real problems that will affect us all.

“I am quietly hopeful that as more and more people become aware of the problems we have to face, there will be a rising tide of people demanding change.

"Small commitments like using less plastic and walking more are just as important, but the change has to be led by the government.”
description: Grannies and grandads have picketed outside the Queen's home in central London in Extinction Rebellion's latest call for action
